subChapters.htmlHeader: Features of lentigines
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Lentigines (singular, lentigo) are very common.
    • Clinical features:
      • Brown or brown-black macule, fairly uniform pigmentation.
      • Usually multiple in number.
      • Varies in size but most commonly less than 5 mm.
      • The edges may be irregular.
  • Types of lentigines
    • Solar lentigo 
      • Most common type of lentigines, often known as 'age spots' or 'liver spots'.
      • Caused by chronic sun exposure.
      • Flat, uniform, brown macules which can expand and become larger than 1 cm.
      • Mainly occur on the sun-exposed skin of middle-aged and older people.
    • Simple lentigo (lentigo simplex) 
      • Commonly appear in childhood.
      • Appear as well-demarcated macules of uniform brown colour.
      • May disappear in adulthood.
    • Ink-spot lentigo
      • A small, densely black macule which usually appears on sun-exposed skin.
      • It may also have an irregular margin, causing diagnostic confusion with melanoma.
  • Images of lentigines are available at www.dermnet.com/Lentigo-Adults and www.dermnet.com/Lentigo-Children.

[Oakley, 2016a; Primary Care Dermatology Society, 2017b]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Features of pigmented basal cell carcinoma
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• A pigmented basal cell carcinoma can appear skin coloured, pink or pigmented brown, blue, or black.
    • Pigmented BCCs are unusual and can be large and ulcerated.
    • May be mistaken for a nodular or superficial spreading malignant melanoma, but basal cell carcinomas usually have a classic translucent rolled edge with telangiectasia.
  • Images of pigmented basal cell carcinomas are available at www.dermnet.com/Basal-Cell-Carcinoma-Pigmented.

[Oakley, 2015b; Primary Care Dermatology Society, 2017c].

subChapters.htmlHeader: Features of seborrhoeic keratoses
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Seborrhoeic keratoses are also known as seborrhoeic warts or basal cell papillomas and are very common.
  • Clinical features include:
    • Flat, pigmented, warty, or smooth, greasy-looking surface.
    • Lesions can vary from 1 mm up to 3 cm.
    • A classical 'stuck on' appearance.
    • Over time they become more prominent and darken in colour, but change is very slow.
    • There are often multiple lesions on the chest and back.
  • Malignant lesions may be difficult to identify on a background of multiple seborrhoeic keratoses, so careful examination is required to exclude malignancies.
  • Unusual seborrhoeic keratoses may need specialist review.
  • Images of seborrhoeic keratoses are available at www.dermnet.com/Seborrheic-Keratoses-Smooth and www.dermnet.com/Seborrheic-Keratosis-Irritated.

[Jackson, 2015; Primary Care Dermatology Society, 2016b]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Features of dermatofibromas
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• A dermatofibroma is:
    • A firm, symmetrical, dermal papule or nodule which is usually 5–15 mm in diameter.
    • Pink, brown or black, depending on the person's skin type.
    • Usually found on the lower extremities in adults.
    • Benign; reassuring features are its symmetry, static nature, and well-defined borders.
  • Dermatofibromas classically dimple when bilateral pressure is applied (sometimes called the 'button hole' sign).
  • Images of dermatofibromas are available at www.dermnet.com/Dermatofibroma.

 [BAD, 2013a; Oakley, 2016b]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Features of freckles
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Freckles (ephelides) are pale brown and macular and usually less than 3 mm in diameter. 
    • Freckles are very common and appear more numerous when the skin is exposed to ultraviolet radiation (UV),
    • Particularly affect people with red hair, fair hair, or fair skin. 
  • Images of freckles are available at www.dermnet.com/Freckles.

[Primary Care Dermatology Society, 2014b]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Features of moles (naevi)
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Benign common moles generally have the following reassuring features:
    • Uniform appearance.
    • Relatively small size.
    • Regular borders.
    • Round or oval shape.
    • Homogeneous surface and colour.
    • Usually correspond to the persons skin type (i.e. light-skinned individuals have lighter moles, dark-skinned individuals have darker moles). 
  • However, the following types of moles may display abnormal or atypical features which may cause diagnostic confusion.
    • Atypical moles or naevi are usually flat and more than 5 mm in diameter. They also have two out of three of the following features: irregular shape; indistinct borders; and variable colours. A person may have numerous atypical naevi, particularly on the trunk and extremities, but they can be found anywhere on the body. They are more likely than other types of naevi to become melanoma (although the absolute risk is very low).
      • In atypical mole syndrome some family members have large numbers of moles and there may be a family history of melanoma. Melanomas can develop within the mole or on normal-appearing skin, therefore removal of the atypical mole does not remove the risk of melanoma. Atypical mole syndrome is seen in around 2% of the UK population and is an important risk factor for melanoma.
      • Images of atypical moles are available at www.dermnet.com/Atypical-Nevi.
    • Halo naevus is surrounded by a depigmented halo of normal skin which is caused by an immunological reaction against the melanocytes in the mole which may cause the pigmented mole to eventually disappear. It is common, especially in older children and young teenagers. Frequently, multiple halo naevi are found, particularly on the back. Halo naevi are usually the result of a benign process, but it is important to examine for a possible underlying malignant melanoma (particularly in adults). Refer if there is any suspicion of malignancy, especially in people older than 30 years of age as halo naevi become rarer with age.
    • Spitz naevus is a firm, round, pink, red or reddish-brown nodule (the colour is due to its vascularity) of less than 2 cm in diameter, which grows rapidly over 3–6 months. It can be blanched by firm pressure to show the melanin pigmentation. It usually occurs on the face or legs in the first two decades of life. Spitz naevi can resemble vascular tumours such as pyogenic granulomas, or a melanoma. Suspected Spitz naevi should be reviewed by a dermatologist to confirm the diagnosis.
    • Meyerson's naevus is a melanocytic naevus with associated epidermal scaling and a halo of inflammation. It is frequently mistaken for a naevus undergoing malignant change.
    • Blue naevus is a raised (papular), smooth lesion which looks like a benign naevus except for the blue or blue-black dermal pigmentation produced by benign collections of melanocytes deep in the dermis. It is usually found on the extremities such as the dorsa of the hands and feet. Although it can resemble malignant melanoma, it is a benign lesion; progressive growth and malignant transformation are very rare. Reassuring features are that it appears in childhood and its static nature.
    • Congenital melanocytic naevi are present from birth or the first 2 years of life. They have have well defined borders, even colour and usually symmetrical. They may sometimes be hairy.
      • Small congenital melanocytic naevi are more common and are usually more than 1.5 cm in diameter.
      • Giant congenital melanocytic naevi can be more than 20 cm in diameter and have malignant potential, with a 9–12% chance of developing melanoma (the risk is greatest before puberty).
      • Naevus spilus is a type of congenital naevus, usually measuring 1–10 cm in diameter. It is a benign lesion which becomes progressively speckled during childhood, with small dark-brown macules and papules within a larger pale brown pigmented patch.
  • Images of moles are available at www.dermnet.com/Melanocytic-Nevi

[Viana, 2013; Oakley, 2014; Primary Care Dermatology Society, 2016c; BMJ Best Practice, 2017a].
